Award.AbstractNarration:
Several technologies have been developed to remediate or enhance the natural remediation of soil and groundwater. Yet, any remediation technology should consider the complex interactions among several mechanisms involved in remediation such as airflow, contaminant flow, seepage, microbial activities, environmental side effects, and cost. It is important to note that most of these existing methods are destructive, costly, or have environmental side effects. For example, using direct and alternating electric currents (DC/AC) need destructive and costly electrode installation. In addition, the soil's electric resistivity increases over time in response to DC/AC, leading to electrode corrosion, efficiency loss, undesirable heating with temperatures over 100oC, and, in the case of DC usage, pH alteration, all of which can compromise the health of soil microbial communities responsible for bioremediation. This team has developed an alternative that leverages electromagnetic (EM) waves to remotely remediate or remove contaminants.

The proposed technology can help industrial fields that deal with multiphase flow, e.g., soil/groundwater remediation, hydrogeology, geophysics, oil recovery, and even earthquake engineering. The technology can benefit owners of contaminated sites ? from private land owners to state / federal agencies and regulatory bodies such as the Environmental Protection Agency. Development of such nondestructive, environmentally safe, versatile, and cost effective remediation technology can have various societal impacts such as human-health improvement, economic benefits, and environmental restoration. This technology can be very cost-effective and nondestructive due to its versatility, because EM waves can be launched using phased-array antennae from above ground; EM radiation patterns can be tailored to contain or move contaminants to extraction wells, enhance airflow and enhance the oxygen delivery to aerobic microbes responsible for bioremediation, and improve contaminants? desorption from the soil matrix.

POR.DRECONTENT:
More than 50% of the U.S. population uses groundwater as their primary source of drinking water. However, every year, more than six million cubic meters of contaminants are dumped into the ground, and more than 10,000 aging underground storage tanks leak into the ground, contaminating groundwater across the U.S.

Mother earth naturally cleans contaminants through natural volatilization and biodegradation. Volatilization is a natural process in which volatile contaminants vaporize and move into the atmosphere to disperse. Biodegradation is another process in which microbes, indigenous to soils, digest and break down contaminants into less-toxic waste. However, these natural processes are extremely slow. There is an urgent need for technologies to clean up contaminated groundwater/soil.

Two categories of remediation technology currently exist. The first category is ex-situ remediation (e.g., dig-and-treat) where contaminated soil or water is extracted and then treated on site or off site. Ex-situ remediation technologies are usually costly and destructive. The second category is in-situ remediation (e.g., air sparging). In-situ remediation is used to enhance and expedite natural volatilization and biodegradation. In-situ techniques face their own limitations due to the restricted, uncontrolled flow of contaminants, air, or oxygen.

Scientists have developed several innovative in-situ technologies to remediate or enhance the natural remediation of soil and groundwater. Most of these methods are destructive, costly, or have environmental side effects. For example, using direct and alternating electric currents (DC/AC) need destructive and costly electrode installation, and the use of DC/AC leads to electrode corrosion, efficiency loss, undesirable heating to temperatures over 100oC, and, in the case of DC, pH alteration. All of these have adverse effects on soil microbial communities responsible for bioremediation.

Using our previous research award from National Science Foundation, we had developed a laboratory-scale technology that uses electromagnetic (EM) waves to help remediate soil and groundwater. EM waves can remove contaminants. EM waves can also help control airflow for air sparging, a method that helps volatile portion  of contaminants evaporate and exit soil.

Some benefits of using EM waves are that EM waves do not alter pH and, as shown by our team, the generated heat by EM waves can be minimized at proper frequencies. Another benefit is that the technology can be cost-effective and nondestructive, because EM waves can be launched using above-ground antennas, eliminating the need for excavation. Unlike DC/AC electrodes, antennas can be cased in PVC casing since they do not transfer electric current into soil, which, in turn, eliminated corrosion. EM-wave radiation patterns can also be tailored to contain contaminants or move them to extraction wells, enhance airflow for air sparging, enhance oxygen supply to aerobic microbes responsible for bioremediation, and many more. EM antennas can even be designed to focus the energy at specific points and leave other points untouched, similar to methods used to treat cancer.

Research outcome may not always get the chance to benefit the public, unless it is commercialized. I-Corps awards focus on equipping researchers with entrepreneurial skills to patent and commercialize their research as well as initiate startup companies and create new jobs, so the researcher have the highest chance of success at transferring their knowledge to a commercial technology.

This project took us through boot-camp workshops to rapidly move a few steps forward toward commercialization of our technology. These steps were: customer interviews to confirm success rate of the technology startup, developing new industrial and agency partnerships, scaling up from laboratory to field, and developing prototypes. In order to find the most successful path to commercialization, one needs to first receive feedback from customers and market. We learned how to perform customer interviews with various stakeholders of remediation industry from public, policy makers, industry, consultants, and landowners. Through these customer interviews facilitated and supported by this award, we received confirmation about the success rate of the transfer and commercialization of our technology. We also learned about a new market for our technology that we had not previously realized. This new market was a submarket of food industry. We also used the resources to help us develop prototypes for both markets as well as network with new international- and small-business partners to move in the direction of scaling up the technology from laboratory to field and field-verify our technology. The project also helped us learn how to patent our technology, which we have already initiated, as well as helped us establish a startup company. We also learned about various ways that a technology could be marketed such as use, selling licenses, and consulting. Using the support provided through this award, we attended two Interstate Technology and Research Council (ITRC) meetings and gave a couple of presentations, interviews, and Q&A (questions and answers) sessions, which lead to publishing our technology on the ITRC’s Upcoming Innovative Technology site for potential application to DNAPL remediation, especially in fractured rock.
